<font size=-1>Department of Plant Pathology and Microbiology, Rothamsted Research Limited,
Click here for a detailed biography that was published in the "Nematology Newsletter" in June 2005 (PDF, 194KB)

I graduated from Hatfield Polytechnic with an Honours Degree in Applied Biology in 1979 with an interest in the area of plant and soil microbiology. After my degree I spent two years working as a plant pathologist at the Shire Valley Agricultural Development Project in Malawi, Africa, and running ICRISAT's sorghum and millet germplasm screening programme and also undertaking some studies on the infection of sorghum roots by mycorrhizae. In 1982 I started a PhD in Plant Biology, at the University College of North Wales Bangor, where I investigated the use of rhizobacteria to promote plant growth. My research takes place within the context of reconciling the conflict between agricultural food production and environmental, economic and social sustainability
column2: in particular the application of science to control of plant parasitic nematodes pests exploiting microbial control agents. I also have an interest in scientific citizenship which includes the public understanding of science and the good governance of science (www.governanceofscience.org). In this context I am curious about how to balance meeting the needs of research scientists, with meeting the needs of the organisations in which they work and the broader needs of society. I am a Fellow of The Linnean Society of London, and have membership to The British Crop Protection Council, The American Society of Nematologists (where I am an editor on their Journal of Nematology), and The Royal Institute of Philosophy. I am also a member of a trades' union Prospect, and sit on the BBSRCs' Joint Negotiating and Consultative Committee.

column1: are thread like metazoans usually less than a millimetre in length that can
live freely in the soil or be parasitic on plants (they are also animal parasites).
The most economically important plant parasitic nematode pests are the sedentary
endoparasites including the cyst and root knot nematodes. These important
crop pests occur in intensive cropping systems and have until recently been
controlled by nematicides. With the withdrawal of
nematicides
from the market, in particular methyl bromide which will be banned from use in
Europe from 2005 (and in developing countries by 2015) alternative approaches
are being sought. Soils can be found which are suppressive to plant parasitic
nematodes and several groups of fungi and bacteria have been identified that
are responsible for suppressing nematode populations to a level at which their
damage does not cause significant economic losses. The application of these micro-organisms
to the soil as biological control agents offers an alternative method to control
these important pests. To date the application of fungi and bacteria to control
these nematodes has produced highly variable results with successes in one situation
but not another. In order for success to be consistently predictable an understanding
of the mechanisms by which these micro-organisms infect and reduce the populations
of their nematode hosts is needed. This requires a thorough understanding from
molecular interactions and the role of functional variation involved in infection
processes, through to the way these molecular interactions, in turn, affect the
population dynamics of both the nematode and its parasite. On the molecular front
my research is aimed at understanding the genetic mechanisms of the interaction
between root-knot nematodes and the bacterium <em>Pasteuria
with Prof. Charlie Opperman's lab, in North Carolina USA, we have embarked on
a genomics project to sequence the genome of this bacterium (<a href="../pubs/kgd/GenomicsBSPPposterweb.pdf" title="Link to Davies BSPP poster" target="_blank">Davies <em>et
al., Genome poster) and have also shown that this bacterium has
a life-cycle very similar to that of Bacillus spp. to which it appears closely
related (<a href="../pubs/kgd/ESN_poster.pdf" title="Link to Davies ESN poster" target="_blank">Davies <em>et
Recently I have spent a sabbatical in Charlie Opperman&rsquo
North Carolina where we have continued to mine the Pasteuria genome for genes
involved in endospore attachment as part of our collaboration. Interestingly,
we have now identified several collagen-like sequences which show similarities
to collagens in other Bacillus spp. (Davies &
a European Union training project I am involved in a study of the role of microbial
enemies of plant parasitic nematodes to affect the colonisation and stability
of marram grass (Ammophila arenaria) in sand dunes (www.nioo.knaw.nl/projects/ECOTRAIN).
It is hoped that the knowledge gained from these studies can be applied to develop
sustainable methods of plant parasitic nematode management by manipulating the
